Yes, they make great games, but they also charge you a huge amount of money for it, and they also make those games by releasing an unfinished product and then adding tons and tons of content throughout the years. There's no escape. It's probably the game where I have spent the most money on DLC in my entire life, and the reason why I try to avoid games that do the same. It's also the reason why I vowed to myself never to play any other Paradox game in my life.

Yes, I understand that the DLC strategy is the reason why they can keep adding new content, but they are just too expensive, and sometimes are not worth the cost. Time and time again, they have added stupid DLCs with only a few images for species, and that's about it. 

I recommend the game because I feel like I would be contradicting myself by not doing so while calling it one of my favorite games at the same time, but I would never recommend playing a Paradox game, especially if you are tight on money. By the time I write this, I have fallen behind for 2 years of content, and I would need to spend a lot of money to buy what I'm missing. Play at your own risk.

After playing this game for a couple of hours, I can easily say it’s one of my favourite 4X titles out there. I’ve only actually beaten the game a couple of times (maybe even only once, for the achievement). There’s no definitive story—only what you choose to do. Whether you want to become a genocidal machine hellbent on eradicating all life in the galaxy, or pursue equality for all and befriend everyone (some not entirely by their own choice), you can do it. Sometimes you may die, sometimes you may become slaves to another empire, but every run can be enjoyable in its own unique way.

Some of the DLC adds high‑quality content to the game, allowing for even more customisation and endless replayability. Others offer a bit less (pick them up on sale if you can).

The game also has a huge variety of mods constantly in development, adding everything from new planet types to new megastructures, all the way to total conversions that turn the base game into something entirely different.

Overall, I would highly recommend purchasing this game, especially if you love 4X strategy games. I would consider it a staple of what a good strategy game can be. That said, late‑game saves can become very laggy for several reasons. It used to be caused by the number of pops across the galaxy; now it’s largely due to the sheer number of ships across all empires. However, the developers are constantly working to improve performance and make the game run as smoothly as possible.

The game is constantly updated and the developers do a great job communicating frequently, listening to feedback, and creating more content constantly. They even in the past updated previous DLC that didn't need to be updated, turning them from cosmetic only packs to something that actually adds to gameplay now. The downside is that they create a ton of new DLC to charge for several times a year, so if you're a completionist it will become rapidly expensive over time, though at least it beats paying the same price for cosmetics in other games. 

The DLC technically are not required. You can get hundreds of hours out of the base game, thanks to how replayable the game is. HOWEVER, they do add a lot to the game and they all start piling onto each other to create bigger and better experiences, making you feel like they're required once you've put some time in. Completely new narratives and playstyles open up with various DLC, ex. if you want more interesting mechanics where your robot species can attain independence instead of being a hive mind, you need to pay for it. Want organic ships and a heavier biological focus? Gotta pay for the DLC. Want the equivalent of the death star, or want to play in a way that allows you to become the new Emperor Palpatine? DLC needed too.

That said, if you're a huge fan of the 4x style and the creative freedom / Role-play opportunities presented in Stellaris, you can get sucked in for hundreds of hours and not mind paying for the DLC to keep the crazy experiences going. Again, just be mindful the costs will add up, but considering how good these developers are compared to other companies, it doesn't feel as bad supporting them compared to paying the same price for cosmetic microtransactions in other games.

The game is not perfect, they do run into ocassional bugs and issues, with the most glaring one at the time of writing frequent multiplayer desyncs that made the game pretty much unplayable in multiplayer settings. Plus, even if you're not happy with their frequent updates, DLC spam, and more, Stellaris has a huge modding community. So if you ever get bored, there's so many different mods to enhance your experience, including complete conversion mods that turn the game into something else entirely (like a Star Wars mod that changes the entire game where every tech, ship, species, etc. is molded to the SW universe, complete with its own narrative and other stuff). The game naturally has a really nice mod launcher, so taking in mods and instructing friends on what to do is very, very simple.

Overall, Stellaris has a lot more positives going for it, with the only real downside being the astronomical costs if you want to keep upgrading your experience and the multiplayer desyncs, though this is not an issue if you prefer playing single player.

Fantastic game, but with some major caveats:
- The DLC's are quite expensive. **However,** if you plan to play multiplayer, only the host needs to own a DLC for everyone to use. And remember, you don't need to get everything.
- Without mods, this game has low replayability. **However,** with the right mods, I would say it has the best endgame of any grand strategy to date. My go-to mods are Gigastructural Engineering, ACOT, and UI overhaul dynamic. I would recommend avoiding gameplay mods (gigastructural and ACOT) for your first few playthroughs.
- Multiplayer desync. It can get annoying, but unlike some other paradox titles, there's the convenient option to just resync everyone without needing to close and reopen your game.
- Updates can cause instability. **However,** you can lock your game to any version you want using the steam beta system (Game->Properties->Betas and then choose the game version you wanna stay on). I recommend doing this if you're doing a modded playthrough. In the event paradox releases an update that causes bugs in vanilla, this is all you need to do to just revert and keep playing while you wait for them to release fixes.

This is my first game review. I have been playing Stellaris for some time now. I have invested probably way too many hours. But the game is addictive and to this day there are still events and scenarios that play out that I have never seen before. Here is what I think of the game. 

The game keeps bringing me back, Pros;
1. It is by far the biggest strategy or RTS I’ve played and I keep playing.
2. There is always a DLC or patch that tries for the most part to make the game better.
3. Massive Mod community – although I tend to like playing in “Iron man” mode for the achieves.
4. Beginning of the game / exploring / fighting other empires and expanding is the best.
5. The RP and random situations of each game keeps pulling me back.
6. The end and mid game crisis are great. Break up the regular game play and force you to deal with the galaxy at large. There is always something happening.
7. Developers are very active in the community. Bugs tend to get fixed and they constantly are ensuring the game is balanced. 
8. There are so many different play styles, each with unique features that give you a different experience when playing. 

The in-between (neither Pro or Con, maybe);
1. The game is massive with a lot of DLC. Great right! But because of the number of DLC getting them all in one go costs way to much.
2. If you want to try all the DLC there is a subscription option that gives you everything. But I hate subscription models and prefer to own my games. However, if you are new and want to try the game with all the DLC then there is at least an option.  

Love the game but there are some Cons;
1. The big maps are cool, but when you get to mid/late game there is a slowdown and alot to manage (there are automation features but I’m here to manage a space empire)
2. Sometime you will come across a bug “in iron man” so no save scumming is available, and that bug will break your game. Sadly having to restart. (this does not happen often but should be mentioned)
3. The learning curve is massive. You will not know what you are doing to start. I myself had to watch a lot of videos to figure out a lot of the systems in the game.
4. Game play mechanics change. Patch 4.0 reworked the game and changed a lot of the base mechanics, to the point where it almost feels like a Stellaris 2 Game. (means you have to re-learn again)
5. Because of all the DLC the game is suffering from a little bit of content bloat. There is a lot happening and a multitude of DLC mechanics to understand. (more videos to watch).

Thoughts;
If you enjoy games like Civ or other RTS games, you should get this game!
If you like to take over the world/galaxy and have other empires serving under you. This game is for you
If you enjoy research trees that give you lasers, This game is for you

if you want to form a galactic republic and work with other empires. You can.
If you want to change your republic into the first galactic empire with you as the leader. You can.

TL:DR - Low replayability, it's not a 4x, it's a bad rp game, lategame is tedious, bad tutorial.

Please note that most of my hours on this game are leaving it on while I am sleeping or at work, I probably have a few dozen real hours.

I'm generally a fan of Paradox games, and there are times where I have enjoyed playing this game, but ultimately I can't recommend it. It's definitely not a HORRIBLE game by any measure, but ultimately I don't think it's worth a large amount of your time or money.

The main flaws of this game is as follows:

1. Lack of Replayability - There simply isn't a lot of meaningful variety across different playthroughs. Take the maps for instance. In a game like Civilization 5 you might play on a Pangea map one playthrough, then a small continents playthrough next time, then an archipelago playthrough the match after that. And even if you played the same civ with the same playstyle, the maps would significantly change the feeling of the game. Here, there is some variety in the map, but there is only so much you can do with outer space, so maps never feel signifacntly different in interesting ways.

The second part that really hurts replayability is that in typical Paradox fashion it is just a blobbing game. To bring up Civilization 5 again, in that game there isn't only conquest victory. There are also things like a peaceful science victory, or a diplomatic victory. The way you win in this game is by getting a large score, which you do by blobbing. Science and diplomacy can help, but at its core this is still a blobbing game, and each playthrough will largely feel similar due to that.

The third part that hurts replayability is the lack of meaningfully different traits. You can make your own custom country where you can say, give them militarism for some extra military bonuses, but it is just a small modifier, and a playthrough where you go spiritualism for a unity bonus doesn't feel that different than going materialism for a robot upkeep bonus. There are SOME traits that spice things up a bit, like fanatic purifier is better at war but can't do diplomacy, or a hivemind doesn't need consumer goods, but these sorts of traits are usually all about REMOVING something from you that you can usually do, so it isn't that interesting or different. There are still some things you can do to spice up your faction when creating them in Stellaris, but at the end of the day I would say you only get maybe 7 good distinct playthroughs or so from that, which is not enough.


2. You buy this game thinking it is a 4x game, but really it is a bad roleplaying game - What I mean by that is if there is no replayability, then what is the appeal of the game? A lot of people who like this game like it for the roleplay aspect. Like I can try and make the Covenant from Halo, or I can try and make the humans from Star Trek. But I think this appeal falls flat because the game doesn't give you a lot to roleplay with, you have to make up your context yourself. There are origins which help a bit, but ultimately if I am roleplaying as the covenant from Halo I give myself maybe the spiritual and militarist traits and that is that, just some small passive buffs. The game is not giving you a lot to work with. 

Compare that to Europa Universalis 4. In that game you play as real historical countries, so you can have those existing cultures to give you an expansive context for your roleplaying. For instance if you are playing as America you have all of American culture to help you imagine how the country you are playing is like, instead of just a few traits you can select from a list. And on top of that you have historical or ahistorical goals to enhance your roleplaying. I get much more immersed conquering the Western Hemisphere as the Inca as compared to conquering some space-faring hivemind as the replicators from Stargate. In the latter you blob just to blob, because that is what Stellaris is about.

3. Lategame is tedious. This is a game where you have to micromanage and it won't be a problem early game, but once you become significantly large and have many planets you will have too much to manage and the entire experience is insufferable. 

There are some good points as well to the game. It is easy to learn for a Paradox game, although not from the tutorial. The tutorial is trash, you need to look up on forums to learn how to play. The discovery and writing is good. (Although you will quickly run into the same events over and over.) The combat is not as tedious as some other 4x games. You can just doomstack. Bombarding planets from orbit is very pretty and quite the power trip.

Well, I really really tried to like this game. I have started several different saves all of which I had to abandon. Now  dont get me wrong, stellaris has some really fun moments like finding the remnants of ancient civilizations, randomly stumbling on new technologies that boost the strength of your ships or helping lost peoples that you can give a home and that might become a powerful ally. But none of that means a thing when you are getting steamrolled by the Ai civs or your resources are drying up and you cant figure out how to fix them. 

Stellaris feels like a game meant for experienced players of the game that will keep buying the ungodly amount of DLC they keep pumping out for the game rather then new players. 

My biggest frustrations with the game: First off, resources. There are a few base resources your empire need to keep running. Energy credits, which is power for your empire. Minerals, which is mainly used to build things on your planets. Alloys, which is used to build ships, mining stations, claim new territory and more. Food, which is... well food and consumer goods which is pretty much resources for the people of your empire. Now you can gain resources on your planets by building specialty buildings for your people to work at, which seems pretty straightforward. You need food? Build a farming facility. Need more alloys? Build a metallurgy. Right? Wrong. See you also have to worry about population because you need workers to fill the jobs. Dont have a high enough population and the jobs wont be filled, which makes sense. So you may think "Alright, i`ll just build the buildings I need and let them fill up with workers as they become available. Right? .... Wrong. Here`s one of the most frustrating things i have regularly encountered. If you have a bunch of buildings build wanting workers the population will keep yeeting themselves between the open jobs without settling on one that needs to be filled. Now, you wont notice this early game because you usually have enough pops to fill all the jobs. But come midgame when you inevitably get a resource deficit thats when all hell breaks loose. See, say you have built a large fleet of ships. It requires quite a lot of energy credits to maintain those ships, so you end up in a deficit. Now the workers see you need more people producing energy so they get pulled away from other jobs say, consumer goods production, to go get you out of that deficit. But as soon as they get to the energy credits jobs and you start getting a decent amount, guess what, youre now running out of consumer goods. So, they throw themselves back to that. And thus begins the resource spiral of death that once starts theres no stopping it. You have to maintain the perfect amount of jobs for your population and at no point does the game warn you that you have too many jobs and not enough workers. In fact its very hard to figure out where your workers even are and what theyre doing. Oh yeah and there are districts for planets too which also require workers and give you resources. Which can only make the death loop worse of you dont understand how to use them. 

second, planet automation. So there is an option to fully automate your planets so they will build the districts and buildings you need and distribute your pops where they need to be automatically. Which sounds awesome and like it would fully fix my first issue. Nope. See from what I could gather planets will only build new buildings\districts if your are in a big deficit for something. And even then it just seems to refuse to build things at times. Whats worse is that if you make a planet dedicated to something other then one of the main resources, say like a planet dedicated to research, it just wont build anything for it. Plain and simple. Trying to automate all my planets is the most pathetic my civilization has ever been. If you automate youre going at a snails pace. If you dont, your resources are gonna go derp. And to strike a balance of the 2 requires babying your planets to the point the game becomes a chore. Just being able to see or getting warned that you have too many jobs for your population would be amazing. 

Third, Ai civ balancing. Yeah doesnt matter if you try to be a full pacifist or full warlord, there will be several Ai empires in your world that will be angry, want to take you over and will completely steamroll you. Unless you play a full pacifist boot licker civ you WILL get steamrolled eventually. And even if you try and go full military mode while you struggle to maintain your two 9K power level fleets over half of the civs around you are able to pump out a dozen 15-20k power level fleets with seemingly no impact on their resources. It`s not fun trying to defend your lands while a full fleet just rolls through you and all you can do is watch your own dinky fleets get massacred. 

Fourth, war weariness. I hate this mechanic so much. So, say that the big rude dudes start rolling through your lands. But you have fleets *just* strong enough to fight back. While you lose territory and some planets you are able to slowly fight them back. You pump out as many ships as you can and go hold your lines. You lose dozens of ships, but you start to push them back. But thats when you notice a little % indicator with your civs icon over it start to tick up from 1% at the bottom of your screen. See with every system, planet, and ship you lose in a war you gain war weariness. And if it reaches 100%, you will be FORCED to make peace with whoever youre fighting, You dont get a choice. So even if you start fighting back and winning, you will still be forced to make peace if you can get your planets and systems back before it gets to 100% (Yeah its a bit after 100% but not long enough to make much of a difference in my opinion.) Oh yeah and theres no way to lower your war weariness in a war. Once its at 100%, thats it. And even if youre the aggressor and are winning a war yourself you can still lose to war weariness. Its a frustrating and poorly thought out mechanic in my opinion. 

I could go on, but I think I made my point so far. I went into this game hoping for a fun galactic adventure. Instead I got bombarded by menus, steamrolled by Ai civs and had my civ doodying itself in every playthrough. Now I know some experienced players are probably reading this and thinking of everything that i`m doing wrong and how to optimally play the game. But that the thing, I`m a newbie player. I dont know how to play the game properly and am trying to learn and gain a love for the game. But it feels like the game is fighting me at every turn and beating me down just when I have something figured out. I`ve had some fun moments with Stellaris, but thats completely drowned out by the constant frustrations ive had with the game. 

If youre an experienced player that knows how the game works and Is diving into each new DLC and loves the game, that`s awesome! Genuinely you should love it. But if youre a new player looking to pick the game up, I could never recommend it to you. There are too many frustrations and confusing aspects of the game in my opinion. I for one dont plan on picking the game up ever again.

I wish I could recommend this game. In my research, there's nothing that quite scratches the itch of playing as a space empire like Stellaris. I might have even come back to it since I wrote this review and enjoyed my time with it, its simply that good on a base level. But the DLC practices are so unbelieveably predatory that they make Space Engineers look like the gold standard. You MUST understand that buying the base game here is only half of the experience. My memory may prove to be my enemy here, because I haven't played since I was last up-to-date with the DLCs (up to Galactic Paragons, if I remember correctly, so my experience might be a touch outdated), but I remember the dozens of hours I sunk into base Stellaris, and while I had a decent bit of fun, it was SO obvious that I was missing DLC. Menus would have a ton of negative space that was obviously filled with expansion content (Federation formation and vassalization menus in particular come to mind). The most egregious instance of this was late into a game where one of the Fallen Empires had awakened and managed to construct a Colossus (an Apocalypse-exclusive feature for players). I was startled and made a post on r/Stellaris about it, to which I received a "thems the brakes" type response. I believe I made this discovery in the era after Nemesis came out, so I thought "Ok, I'll just dump the money on it incrementally. I love this game, might as well pay a bit for the full deal." 

I proceeded to do so, chipping away at the DLCs until I caught up with all of them. This was shortly after they announced the Custodian Initiative, which is something I LOVED. I still maintain that every game with a long-term lifespan should have a dedicated team to looking at old features to make sure they aren't getting creeped out of usefulness. Paradox really had a master stroke with that decision. I won't engage in hearsay, as its unbecoming of me to do so, but I HAVE heard that the Custodians have been...slacking off, so to speak. Their recent contributions haven't been as effective at their jobs as of late (allegedly).

Fast forward to a few months ago, I get the itch to play the game again. It was after a holiday (or my birthday) and I had some gift cards to spend. I went and shoved all of the new DLCs into a cart to see what I was looking at to get back into the game. It was $80. I IMMEDIATELY did a metaphorical heel turn and said "F*** this, I could be giving this money to a smaller studio who actually needs it" and purchased a couple games I had been eyeballing for some time. I loved those two games, but I eventually came to yearn for a Stellaris playthrough again. I couldn't bring myself to get up-to-date on the DLCs. Some combination of FOMO and a moral compass prevented me from doing so. I told myself I wouldn't buy Cosmic Storms, which had scathing reviews claiming that the DLC only made the game worse, but I got worried that I would be missing out. After all, I HAD enjoyed Nemesis, and that wasn't very highly praised at the time, so what's to say I was being premature in my judgement?

Where I'm going with this, this admittedly strange and somewhat subjective anecdote, is the FEELING getting evoked. I WANT to play the game, but I took a break from it for so long that the DLCs piled up. I KNOW how bad it is to play the game with only some of the DLCs, so I declare that I won't play the game without the complete DLC set. I go to buy the rest of the DLCs, see the price (upwards of $100 at this point), realize the amount of money I've sunk into the game/decide that Paradox doesn't deserve this money (it's a coin toss), and forget about it. I've been cycling through this since the beginning of the last paragraph. It's quite a damn shame that it has to be like this. This game is an easy recommend, in another universe, another time, but not this one. I cannot in good conscience recommend a game that is effectively a $40 demo containing a continuously-dwindling portion of the full game.
